title: Hamm's beer advertising font
content:
anyone know what the font is for the Hamm's logo, might be hand drawn, and/or the headline font from the print ads? see attached.  
thanks, liz

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141116092436im_/http:/typophile.com/files/hamms_1953_ice_00_5212.jpg)
author: lizthiem

comments.content:
A fun, similar replacement for the headline might be Ed Roman.  
 [http://www.houseind.com/index.php?page=showfont&id=150&subpage=viewfonts](http://web.archive.org/web/20141116092436/http:/www.houseind.com/index.php?page=showfont&id=150&subpage=viewfonts "http://www.houseind.com/index.php?page=showfont&id=150&subpage=viewfonts")

Because the Hamm's brand predates the digital age of type, the lettering of the logo must have been hand drawn. I think. And that's precisely what's so great about nostalgic graphic design like this example. We cannot expect to replicate the same unique charm with short-cut logos created with fonts.

Koppa speaks the truth. You might dig [La Salle](http://web.archive.org/web/20141116092436/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/elsner_flake/la_salle_regular_ot/), [Amorinda](http://web.archive.org/web/20141116092436/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/sudtipos/amorinda_regular_ot/) or [Malbeck](http://web.archive.org/web/20141116092436/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/sudtipos/malbeck_regular_ot/).

that's so true, koppa.  
thanks for the font ideas guys.  
love this site!
